H0.text: Specialization occurs when competing species evolve different adaptations.

H1.text: Evolution occurs when competing species evolve different adaptations.

H2.text: Urbanization occurs when competing species evolve different adaptations.

H3.text: Rate adaptation is the process that occurs when competing species evolve different adaptations.

A4.text: The rationale for character displacement stems from the competitive exclusion principle, also called Gause's Law, which contends that to coexist in a stable environment two competing species must differ in their respective ecological niche; without differentiation, one species will eliminate or exclude the other through competition.

A5.text: When American mink (Mustela vison) were introduced in north-eastern Belarus, the native European mink (Mustela lutreola) increased in size, and the introduced mink decreased in size. This displacement was observed within a ten-year study, demonstrating that competition can drive rapid evolutionary change.

A6.text: Once they occurred in sympatry, niche specialization was favored so that the different species competed less directly for resources.

A7.text: Intraspecific competition will increase, promoting divergent selection to use a wider range of resources.

A8.text: This tends to drive the speciation of more specialized species provided conditions remain relatively stable.

A9.text: This involves niche partitioning as new species are formed, and biodiversity is increased.
